tn.text: Festus has brought Paul before King Agrippa. In verse 2, Paul gives his defense to King Agrippa.
Agrippa was the current reigning king in Palestine, though he ruled over only a few territories. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:act:25:13|25:13]].
"gestured with his hand toward the crowd to get their attention"
The abstract noun "defense" can be stated as a verb. AT: "began to defend himself against those who were accusing him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Paul was happy because he considered his appearance before Agrippa to be an opportunity to speak about the gospel.
This phrase means to describe one's situation, so that those in court can discuss and make a decision about it. AT: "to defend myself"

tn.ref: against all the accusations of the Jews
tn.text: The abstract noun "accusations" can be stated as the verb "accuse." AT: "against all the Jews who are accusing me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This does not mean all the Jews. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
You can make explicit what kinds of questions this means. AT: "and questions about religious matters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: all the Jews know how I lived ... at Jerusalem
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Pharisees who grew up with Paul and knew him as a Pharisee or 2) Paul was well known among the Jews due to his zeal as a Pharisee and now as a believer.
This is an exaggeration that emphasizes that many Jews know about Paul. AT: "many Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Possible meanings are 1) among his own people, not necessarily in the geographical land of Israel or 2) in the land of Israel.

tn.ref: a very strict sect of our religion
tn.text: "a group within Judaism who live by very strict rules"
Here "you" is plural and refers to the people who were listening to Paul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This word marks a shift from Paul discussing his past to talking about himself in the present.

tn.ref: I stand here to be judged
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I am here, where they are putting me on trial" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I look for the promise that God made to our fathers
tn.text: This speaks about a promise as if it were something a person could look for and see. AT: "I am waiting expectantly for God to do what he promised our forefathers he would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For this is the promise our twelve tribes hoped to receive
tn.text: The phrase "our twelve tribes" stands for the people in those tribes. AT: "This is also what our fellow Jews in the twelve tribes were waiting for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This speaks about a promise as if it were an object that can be received. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The extremes "night" and "day" mean they "worshiped God continually." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
This does not mean all the Jews. AT: "that the leaders of the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Why should any of you think it is incredible that God raises the dead?
tn.text: Paul uses a question to challenge the Jews present. They believe God can raise the dead but do not think God brought Jesus back to life. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "You should not think it is incredible that God brings a dead person back to life." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Paul uses this phrase to mark another shift in his defense. He is now accounting how he used to persecute the saints.
The word "name" here stands for Jesus himself. AT: "to stop people from believing in Jesus" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: and when they were killed, I cast my vote against them
tn.text: The phrase "were killed" can be stated in active form. AT: "and I voted in agreement with the other Jewish leaders to condemn believers to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Possible meanings are 1) Paul punished some believers many times or 2) Paul punished many different believers.
While talking to King Agrippa, Paul tells about his talking to the Lord.
Paul uses this phrase to mark another shift in his defense. He is now telling about when he saw Jesus and became his disciple.
This word is used to mark two events that are happening at the same time. In this case, Paul went to Damascus during the time when he persecuted Christians.
Paul had written letters from the Jewish leaders, granting him authority to persecute the Jewish believers.

tn.ref: I heard a voice speaking to me that said
tn.text: Here "voice" stands for the person speaking. AT: "I heard someone speaking to me who said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: It is hard for you to kick a goad
tn.text: For Paul to resist Jesus and to persecute believers is spoken of as if he were an ox kicking at the sharp stick that a person uses to prod the animal. It means that Paul is only harming himself. AT: "You will only harm yourself like an ox kicking a goad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul continues giving his defense to King Agrippa. In these verses he continues quoting his conversation with the Lord.
Helping people to understand the truth is spoken of as if a person were literally helping someone to open his eyes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to turn them from darkness to light
tn.text: Helping someone to stop doing what is evil and to start trusting and obeying God is spoken of as if the person is literally leading someone out of a dark place into a place of light. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to turn them ... from the power of Satan to God
tn.text: Helping someone to stop obeying Satan and to start obeying God is spoken of as if a person were literally turning a person and taking them from the place where Satan rules and leading him to the place where God rules. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they may receive from God the forgiveness of sins
tn.text: The abstract noun "forgiveness" can be stated as the verb "forgive." AT: "God may forgive their sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "inheritance" may be stated as the verb "inherit." AT: "they may inherit that which I give" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The blessings that Jesus gives to those who believe in him are spoken of as if they were an inheritance that children receive from their father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jesus choosing some people to belong to him is spoken of as if he literally set them apart from other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"because they believe in me." Here Paul finishes quoting the Lord.
This word marks a statement because of what was said previously. In this case, Paul had just explained what the Lord had commanded him in his vision.
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "I obeyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
This refers to what the person in the vision told Paul. AT: "what the person from heaven told me in the vision" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
To start trusting God is spoken of as if a person turns to start walking toward God. AT: "trust in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The abstract noun "repentance" can be stated as the verb "repented." AT: "and start doing good deeds to show they truly have repented" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This does not mean all of the Jews. AT: "some Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Paul finishes giving his defense to King Agrippa.
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "about the exact thing that"
Paul is referring to the collective writings of the Old Testament prophets.
You can make explicit that Christ must also die. AT: "that Christ must suffer and die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: he would be the first from the resurrection of the dead ones to rise
tn.text: The abstract noun "resurrection" can be stated as "bringing people back to life." AT: "he would be the first person to rise from among the dead ones when God starts bringing people back to life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The phrase "the dead ones" refers to the spirits of people who have died. To come back from among them means to become alive again.

"to proclaim the message about the light." To tell people about how God saves people is spoken of as if a person were speaking about the light. AT: "to proclaim the message about how God saves people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul and King Agrippa continue to talk together.
"you are speaking nonsense" or "you are crazy"

tn.ref: your great learning makes you insane
tn.text: "you have learned so much that you are now crazy"
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "I am sane ... and" or "I am able to think well ... and" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"Festus, who deserves highest honors"

tn.ref: I speak words of truth and soberness
tn.text: Here "words" stands for Paul's message. AT: "I speak a message that is true and serious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: For the king ... to him ... from him
tn.text: Paul is still speaking to King Agrippa, but he is referring to him in the third person. AT: "For you ... to you ... from you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "I am sure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: that none of this is hidden from him
tn.text: This can be stated in active and positive form. AT: "that he is aware of this" or "that you are aware of this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: has not been done in a corner
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "has not happened in a corner" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

This means doing something in secret as if a person went and did something in the corner of a room where no one can see him. AT: "in a dark place" or "in secret" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do you believe the prophets, King Agrippa?
tn.text: Paul asks this question to remind Agrippa that Agrippa already believes what the prophets said about Jesus. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "You already believe what the Jewish prophets said, King Agrippa." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: In a short time would you persuade me and make me a Christian?
tn.text: Agrippa asks this question to show Paul that he cannot convince Agrippa so easily without more proof. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "Surely you do not think you can convince me so easily to believe in Jesus!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "prison chains" stands for being a prisoner. AT: "but, of course, I do no want you to be a prisoner like I am" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This ends Paul's time before King Agrippa.
Bernice was the sister of King Agrippa. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:25:13|25:13]])

tn.ref: Then the king stood up, and the governor
tn.text: "Then King Agrippa stood up, and Governor Festus"
This is a large room for ceremonies, trials, and other events.

tn.ref: This man does nothing worthy of death or of bonds
tn.text: The abstract noun "death" can be stated as the verb "die." Here "bonds" stands for being in prison. AT: "This man does not deserve to die or to be in prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: This man could have been freed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "This man could have gone free" or "I could have freed this man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
